timeline.message:
Search memory leak

Search could leak memory if global ordinals were calculated as part of
a search with low level cancellation enabled. Search registers a
cancellation on the reader that is never removed, which ends up being
referenced from the global ordinals cache entry. This keeps an indirect
reference to the search context. The main known leak occurs when a
cardinality aggregation is used and the pages backing the hyperlog++
are not recycled when it is closed.

This commit also fixes request breaker adjustment in cardinality
aggregation.

timeline.bodyText: Since we use the ContextIndexSearcher only in DefaultSearchContext I wonder if that would be cleaner to extend Closeable and to close the searcher here ?
timeline.author: jimczi

timeline.bodyText: What is your plan with this test ? I don't think it's necessary to commit at least not in this form ?
timeline.author: jimczi

replies.bodyText:
I was torn on this too. I dislike the extended runtime and GC checking. It would be nice to be able to catch such leaks, but I recognize that it is probably better handled elsewhere (like rally and monitoring for heap usage).
I replaced it with an integration test that only verifies that the request breaker accounting is done correctly for cardinality aggs (and discovered a bug I introduced in the process).
replies.author: henningandersen

timeline.message: Make integration test target request breaker only.

timeline.bodyText: Can you add a comment on why we're clearing the list on close ? It's easy to forget and/or to remove if we don't explain the possible leak in the reader.
timeline.author: jimczi
